Cyclist magazine issue 139: on sale now!

Issue 139, June 2023, of Cyclist magazine is on sale now. Subscribe to Cyclist here or buy issue 139 at the Cyclist Shop

This issue of Cyclist, I’ve been embracing my inner youth, as well as my inner fusty old man. I can only assume I’m going through a cycling midlife crisis as I swing between acting my age and refusing to grow up.

Firstly, there’s my trip to the Scottish island of Islay – undertaken last summer – where the challenge is less about scaling epic peaks and more about getting around as many distilleries as possible before the last ferry departs. This is me in full-on old buffer mode, and it’s the kind of thing that a younger me would have rolled my eyes at – a bunch of guys pootling around on bikes, tasting malt whisky and gassing about smoky top notes.

Then there’s my review of the new YT Szepter bike. It’s just about the closest thing to a mountain bike that this magazine has ever featured (it says it’s a gravel bike, but the suspension fork and dropper post would suggest otherwise) and saw me skidding around muddy trails in my local woods like some baggies-wearing teenager. It’s the kind of thing that geriatric me would bemoan as being another nail in the coffin of traditional road riding values – it’s all been going to the dogs since road bikes got disc brakes, don’t you know.

So which am I? The whisky-sipping old fart who reminisces about steel frames, 19mm tyres and appreciates a drink that comes with tasting notes, or the born-again renegade sticking two fingers up to tradition and considering getting a leg tattoo?

I suspect the truth is that I’m both these things, and neither. I’m simply responding to a road cycling landscape that is in a state of flux as manufacturers expand the remit and capabilities of their bikes, and a new generation of riders emerges with new views about what the sport should be about.

As YT’s product development manager, Frank Dörr, says when explaining the thinking behind the Szepter, ‘We just want to bring together different kinds of people, different genres.’

Youth and oldies getting along? Roadies and off-roadies living in harmony? A cycling world free of tribes? It’s a crazy idea, but it might just work.

Pete Muir Editor

What’s in issue 139?

Switzerland’s gift to the Giro: In May, the Giro d’Italia will cross the border to visit the Croix de Coeur in Switzerland. But not before Cyclist uncovers a magical loop hidden among the 4,000m peaks of the Swiss Alps

Up front: Over the past few years, Orla Chennaoui has established herself as the face of pro cycling in her role as lead presenter on Eurosport. She tells Cyclist about sticking to her values, her favourite cycling rivalry and why women’s racing is more exciting than ever

Pico de Veleta: Conquering Europe’s highest paved road is a war of attrition

Scott Addict: When it first appeared 16 years ago, the Scott Addict was the lightest racing bike in the world. It’s still pushing the boundaries of lightness – and winning races – today

No sleep till Kigali: The Race Around Rwanda is an ultra-endurance loop of the Land of a Thousand Hills – part bikepacking odyssey, part study in sleep deprivation. Cyclist learns about freezing rain, spiders and hallucinations on the red gravel roads of Africa

Whisky galore: For whisky lovers, there is no better place to visit than the Scottish island of Islay. Cyclisht shaddlesh up for tour of itsh many dishtilleriesh
